answer_html: \(\displaystyle (2^{18})^{2} \equiv 2^{36} \equiv 1 \mod{1729}\)and this is a contradiction.Hence 1729 is not prime.
answer_latex: $\displaystyle (2^{18})^{2} \equiv 2^{36} \equiv 1 \mod{1729}$and this is a contradiction.Hence 1729 is not prime.
hints_html: This idea is similar to the idea in Miller’s Test. Suppose that 1729 is prime. How many solutions should \(\displaystyle x^{2} - 1 \equiv 0 \mod{1729}\) have?
hints_latex:
This idea is similar to the idea in Miller's Test. Suppose that 1729 is
prime. How many solutions should
$\displaystyle x^{2} - 1 \equiv 0 \mod{1729}$ have?
hints_raw: This idea is similar to the idea in Miller's Test. Suppose that 1729 is prime. How many solutions should <math> \displaystyle x^{2} - 1 \equiv 0 \mod{1729}</math> have?
question: 4 (c)
sols_html:
Assume towards a contradiction that 1729 is prime. Look at

\(\displaystyle x^{2} \equiv 1 \mod{1729}\)

If this were prime, we would have that the only two solutions to this equation are given by \(\displaystyle x \equiv 1 \mod{1729}\) and \(\displaystyle x \equiv -1 \mod{1729}\) (if you haven’t seen this before, isolate for 0, factor and argue that because we’ve assumed that 1729 is prime, it has to divide one of the factors). However, notice that from the given congruences, we have that \(\displaystyle 2^{18} \not\equiv \pm 1 \mod{1729}\) but

\(\displaystyle (2^{18})^{2} \equiv 2^{36} \equiv 1 \mod{1729}\)

and this is a contradiction. Hence 1729 is not prime.

sols_raw:
Assume towards a contradiction that 1729 is prime. Look at

<math> \displaystyle x^{2} \equiv 1 \mod{1729}</math>

If this were prime, we would have that the only two solutions to this equation are given by <math> \displaystyle x \equiv 1 \mod{1729}</math> and <math> \displaystyle x \equiv -1 \mod{1729}</math> (if you haven't seen this before, isolate for 0, factor and argue that because we've assumed that 1729 is prime, it has to divide one of the factors). However, notice that from the given congruences, we have that <math> \displaystyle 2^{18} \not\equiv \pm 1 \mod{1729}</math> but

<math> \displaystyle (2^{18})^{2} \equiv 2^{36} \equiv 1 \mod{1729}</math>

and this is a contradiction. Hence 1729 is not prime.
statement_html:
Show, without using the explicit prime factorization of 1729, but using the following congruences instead, that 1729 is composite.

\[\begin{aligned} 2^{18} &\equiv 1065 \mod{1729} \\ 2^{36} &\equiv 1 \mod{1729}\end{aligned}\]
